topics.title: Skills-first hiring during early COVID shock
topics.summary: Hari describes March 2020 job-loss waves and why labor didn’t rebalance quickly due to title-based matching. He introduces LinkedIn’s push for skills-first hiring to translate experience into skills and improve mobility across roles.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny explains how a tweet led to inviting Hari, and frames Hari’s role leading Talent Solutions (hiring + learning). He previews topics including hiring market changes, job-seeking tips, complex systems, and LinkedIn’s content evolution.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Miro (collaborative whiteboard) and Brave Search API (independent search index for AI/search apps).

topics.title: LinkedIn feed becomes more valuable content
topics.summary: Lenny asks why LinkedIn feels less “cringe” and more useful; Hari explains the company’s North Star of connecting people to economic opportunity and how feed decisions prioritize relationships and knowledge/advice content.

topics.title: Algorithm, ML, and genAI for knowledge
topics.summary: They discuss what changed in the feed: better clarity on what members want, ML-driven ranking, and early genAI-assisted prompts to unlock expertise from nearly a billion members. Hari notes knowledge/advice tends to perform well.

topics.title: Talent Solutions scope: hiring and learning marketplaces
topics.summary: Hari outlines Talent Solutions as two marketplaces—hiring (seekers and recruiters) and learning (learners and instructors)—and explains how LinkedIn products interlock (feed ↔ jobs ↔ network ↔ learning). He also shares behind-the-scenes details like LinkedIn Learning studios.

topics.title: Hiring market shifts: skills and values-based discovery
topics.summary: Hari confirms the market has more seekers and fewer jobs, but argues structural changes persist. He highlights skills-first hiring adoption (recruiters searching by skills) and new ways people browse jobs by values/purpose/interest via collections.

topics.title: Open to Work evolution and internal mobility signals
topics.summary: They discuss how “Open to Work” moved from a private recruiter signal to a public frame, especially during COVID when stigma changed. Hari previews experimentation with “Open to Internal Work” to help employees find internal roles despite cultural sensitivities.

topics.title: PM hiring trends and job-seeker tactics
topics.summary: Hari shares data that tech hiring is down ~50% YoY and PM roles are similarly pressured. He advises building relationships, adding evidence/credentials to skills on LinkedIn, and differentiating via relevant industry domain knowledge.

topics.title: Improving recruiter discovery: intent and skills signals
topics.summary: Hari explains recruiters look for (1) intent and (2) skills, and points to features like Open to Work targeting, expressing interest on company pages, and attaching work products/recommendations to skill entries. He notes Open to Work and skills evidence correlate with better outcomes.

topics.title: Senior hiring: recruiting vs job applications
topics.summary: They discuss how more senior roles (e.g., CPO) are often filled via outbound recruiting and networking rather than clicking “apply,” though postings exist. LinkedIn is positioned as a relationship and signal layer for long-term recruiting.

topics.title: LinkedIn culture: North Star and decision clarity
topics.summary: Hari recounts a tough first product review after joining via acquisition and how reframing around the North Star—connecting people to economic opportunity—changed outcomes. They discuss how repetition and cultural “immune system” keep teams aligned, plus concrete marketplace metrics like hires and learning time.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Eppo, an A/B testing and experimentation platform for modern growth teams.

topics.title: Building complex ecosystems: second-order effects and governance
topics.summary: Hari explains how complex systems require anticipating multi-step cause-and-effect and measuring downstream impacts. He describes decision frameworks like RAPID (roles in decisions) and a five-day escalation/alignment rule to unblock cross-team complexity.
